issue.description: Certain clauses such as fundamental concepts are required by current xslt, but are not required by SDs.
1. In the header "TECHNICAL SPECIFICATION ISO/TS 10303-1250" you need to add ":2004(E)" -- see our model attached for an International Standard.
2. The introductory and main elements of the title should run on, i.e. no line break between them necessary.
3. The trailing em rule at the end of the main element of the title is not necessary (because there is a line break).
5. It is ugly to include a colon in the part title as shown in the example you attached since you then have two consecutive colons: "Part #. Xxxxxxxxxx: Xxxxx"

comment.description:
Re. point 5 and double colon: If that's the way that you've done it in the past then I can't really argue but its not usual English usage and frankly is odd. I would have thought something like Industrial automation systems and integration Product data representation and exchange Part 1250: Application module "Attachment slot"
or
"Attachment slot" application module or
Industrial automation systems and integration Product data representation and exchange application modules Part 1250: Attachment slot was more usual English. Maybe bear it in mind for the next generation?
Issue closed based on comment from ISO above.

issue.description: 8. In the link to the document "ISO 10303-1250" the text should be the full reference No., i.e. in this example "ISO/TS 10303-1250:2004(E)"
9. There are two spaces beween "First" and "edition" -- there should only be one. In place of "2004" please put the full publication date "2004-12-01".

comment.description: Space issue addressed. See RBN-14 for debate on publication date.

issue.description: their DIS example has ISO/DIS #####-## ICS ##.###.##; ##.###.## It does not have the edition. I assume that the edition is required, so I have changed it to: ISO/DIS 10303-239:2004(E) First edition 2004 ICS ##.###.##; ##.###.##

comment.description:
No we don't put the edition on the DIS. What we do do, if the DIS is a revision of another standard, is to put under the title [Revision of Xxxxx edition (ISO ####:####)]
See the attached DIS for an example. This is of course not in HTML but is sufficient to give you the general idea. Off hand I don't recall a case of an HTML DIS which is a revision but if you are desperate I can always dig so let me know.
Corrected (stepmod/xsl/publication/pub_isocover.xsl)Check resource docs. Check resource docs.
